traceability.evidence: Inspection of src/fetch-version-times.js shows that it always runs `npm view time --json` and returns dates for all versions (excluding only “created”/“modified”), but there is no logic anywhere to restrict or filter the fetch to only versions newer than the current. In src/print-outdated.js, after fetching all version times, only the publish date of the single `latest` version is used to calculate and display an age; intermediate versions newer than current are neither filtered nor displayed. No tests cover or enforce any “smart fetching” behavior. This means the REQ-OPTIMIZATION (“Only fetch versions newer than current”) and the acceptance criterion “Smart Fetching” are not met.
traceability.notes: The code correctly uses `npm view ... time --json`, calculates age in days via age-calculator, and displays an age for the latest version, satisfying core functionality, age calculation, and display. However, it fails to implement the optimization to fetch or process only versions newer than the current version, and it does not display ages for all newer versions as scoped by the story.
